I remember going on a long time trying to convince myself that goblin sharks aren’t real until I finally had the courage to use my voice & do my own research ... in 3rd grade we had to do an animal “research paper” and I wanted to write about goblin sharks, when I told my teacher she called me stupid and said those aren’t real. I felt very embarrassed bc everyone heard and laughed. I was doing my own research at the age of 7 while my teacher who was in her late forties didn’t even believe in speciation, heck probably not even in evolution. Currently, I’m a third year biology major

hey, editorial note! i dont know if you guys will even see this but, goblin sharks are not actually flabby in the water! they only look so gross and weird when theyve been removed from the deep waters they normally live in, where pressure is much greater and intense compared to the light fluffy atmosphere we have up here. they get crushed under their own density (an adaptation needed for living so deep) and get all flabby.

you can see how they REALLY look in that little diagram you showed of the stills of the shark flinging its jaws out, when its mouth is retracted! at 4:57

this same stigma is placed around the blobfish, another deep dwelling marine animal who, when removed from the water, looks like a blob. but in the water, it looks pretty normal!

4:55 that’s actually incorrect. The DEACON that bursts out of the Engineer in Prometheus uses the goblin shark’s jaw effect in the movie. The Xenomorphs that attacked Ripley have what’s called a pharyngeal jaw, which eels are rarely acknowledged to have (except the eels don’t use it to attack, but to pull their prey down their gullet since they can’t actually swallow).

Greenland sharks are virtually all blind. A type of Copepod attaches itself to the shark's cornea, which it slowly eats. It is thought that this occurs because the Greenland shark moves so slowly young copepods can catch them. The Copepods look like a tassel attached to the eyeball.

This list could’ve been so long, honestly, if runtime wasn’t an issue. There are so many insanely interesting shark species out there. Even some of the “Hollywood classics” are a lot cooler than people give them credit for (thanks, film industry). The bull shark can regulate its own salinity, which allows it to move back and forth between salt and fresh water. The tiger shark is just known for eating whatever the hell it wants (there’s a story out there of scientists cutting open a tiger shark to find a live Inuit fisherman inside). The mako shark is incredibly fast. The cookie cutter shark bites circular holes in its very large prey (dolphins, whales, etc.) instead of eating it entirely (hence the name), and has been known to go after submarines. The basking shark is a huge filter-feeding species that has an absolutely gigantic mouth. It literally just basks in the open water as tiny organisms swim into its huge, gaping maw. Hammerheads have, as the name suggests, hammer-shaped heads that are used to dig up prey from in the sand. They have an eye on either side of the “hammer”, and so have to turn their heads back and forth as they swim in order to see in front of them. The whale shark is a massive shark (up to 50 feet long) that’s entirely peaceful. It’s another filter feeder. There are sharks out there that are livebearers, which is super cool. There’s also just a crazy amount of diversity among egg shapes and sizes.

And this is all to do with sharks that still exist. You’ve also got prehistoric oddities like the guy with the weird wheel jaw, or the one with bristles on its head.

In summary, sharks are incredibly fascinating creatures, and you should totally learn more about them.

Yea!  I live on the SW coast of Australia!  Seen a few Noah’s as I love to free dive for abalone and crayfish (lobster) .  Lots of seals and even more great white sharks.  They are a very efficient and intelligent predator.  I’ve bumped one off and swam at speed from a few.  They are not to be fkd with.  Most people have no clue they are there until the teeth sink in.  Evolution has provided them the perfect camouflage.  Blue grey skin on top,  bright white belly, as they hunt from below, thrusting upwards to strike,  like I said most don’t see the coming.  Come to Australia for a holiday but, be smart.

Fun fact from a former aquarist. The Spotted Wobbegong can strike faster than the average human reaction time. If you get too close, they will literally bite you before you realize it. Also the tassels on their face help to break up their outline within coral structures, which is how most animals identify things (we notice patterns).

The teeth of the Frilled Shark, remind me of the Crabeater Seals teeth. They are not used to eat crabs, but instead are used to sieve Krill from seawater taken into the mouth. Which would explain why the teeth are backwards to what would be expected, instead of pulling something in, they are there to prevent Krill for example escaping when water is expelled from the mouth.

Surprised that the Cookie Cutter sharks didn't make this list, being that they're named for the way they grab onto larger fish and just sort of wiggle around in a circle, cutting out "cookie shaped" chunks of flesh to eat. During the cold war, Cookie Cutter sharks often tried to eat submarines, and sometimes damaged their sonar equipment in the process. For a long time, the U.S thought that the Soviets were using some kind of new anti-sonar technology against them until they discovered it was a bunch of misguided sharks.

You forgot Epaullette sharks, which live in tidal reefs and hunt at low tide by walking across the ground from pool to pool, searching for stranded prey. They can survive outside of water for upwards of eight hours by shutting off parts of their brain to conserve energy and reduce the amount of oxygen they need. Also they are the only species of shark able to reproduce in captivity, as other species require too much space and are too easily stressed.

The Jaw structure of the Alien from Alien is called a Pharyngeal jaw (a second set of jaws). The Moray Eel actually has a set of Jaws that looks and function identically to the movie monster. Although, according to Wikipedia it wasn't discovered until 2007.
